issues.description: Interface name mismatch: the problem statement (and the UML) define an interface named 'Milkable' with the abstract method messageOnMilk(), and the template's Main class (commented code) also refers to 'Milkable'. The solution repository, however, provides an interface named 'Dairy' (with messageOnMilk()) and leaves Milkable.java empty. This inconsistency (different interface name + an empty Milkable file) will confuse students about which interface to implement and will break compatibility with tests or starter code that expect 'Milkable'.
issues.suggested_fix: Make interface naming consistent across artifacts. Replace or rename the solution's 'Dairy' interface to 'Milkable' (i.e., define messageOnMilk() in Milkable) and remove the empty Milkable.java, or have Milkable extend/alias Dairy but ensure only one appropriately-named interface is used by all classes and by the template. Update all classes (Seal, Goat, etc.) to implement 'Milkable' and update any references (including Main and tests) accordingly so the interface name matches the problem statement and UML.

issues.description: The problem statement and template refer to the milking capability/interface as 'Milkable' (interface Milkable with method messageOnMilk()), but the solution implementation introduces an interface named 'Dairy' and has the animal classes (Seal, Goat) implement 'Dairy'. This creates a naming mismatch for the same conceptual entity (the milking interface) across artifacts: students reading the problem/template will look for or implement 'Milkable', whereas the solution uses the different identifier 'Dairy'. The solution even contains an empty Milkable.java file, further indicating an unintended inconsistency. This divergence breaks direct mapping between requirement (Milkable) and the provided solution (Dairy) and will confuse students attempting to compare or align their code with the reference.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the interface name across all artifacts. Preferred fixes (choose one):
1) Rename the solution's Dairy interface to Milkable (file Dairy.java -> Milkable.java) and have Seal and Goat implement Milkable. Remove any empty/duplicate Milkable.java. Ensure the interface declares String messageOnMilk();
OR
2) Update the problem statement and template to refer to the interface as 'Dairy' instead of 'Milkable' (less recommended since the template and UML currently use 'Milkable').
The first option preserves the UML and template wording and minimizes student confusion.
